metadata.description: This data was derived from "1: 100,000 Land Use Data of China". Based on Landsat MSS, TM and ETM remote sensing data, 1: 100,000 Land Use Data of China was compiled within three years by a remote sensing scientific and technological team of 19 research institutes affiliated to the Chinese Academy of Sciences, which was organized by the “Remote Sensing Macroinvestigation and Dynamic Research on the National Resources and Environment", one of the major application programs in Chinese Academy of Sciences during the "Eighth Five-year Plan". This data adopts a hierarchical land cover classification system, which divides the country into 6 first-class categories (cultivated land, forest land, grassland, water area, urban and rural areas, industrial and mining areas, residential land and unused land) and 31 second-class categories. This is the most accurate land use data product in our country at present. It has already played an important role in national land resources survey, hydrology and ecological research.
metadata.instructions:
File name: data is stored in vector SHP format, and the file name is "Ningxia-2000" ;
Data reading: it can be opened and read by remote sensing software such as ArcGIS and QGIS.

background: Land-use/cover change has become an event being of paramount importance to the study of global environmental change. Land-cover change is closely related to the terrestrial surface material cycles and life-support processes, i.e., the interaction between biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, biogeochemical cycle and sustainable exploitation of resources. The series of scientific study programs, issued and promoted by IGBP and IHDP in 1995, make the study of land-use and land-cover change (LUCC) become one of the hot topics in the global environmental change study. As a developing but booming country, China has formulated a series of policies exerting great influence on the land-use change. In addition, due to varied physical environments and vast land areas, its land-use changes not only influence the social and economic development but also impact the global change accordingly.
research objective: In this paper, the division of dynamic regionalization of land-use change is designed, for the sake of revealing the temporal and spatial features of land-use change and laying the foundation for the study of regional scale land-use changes. The paper exerts an effective effort on the integrated studies of “spatial pattern” and “temporal process” for land-use change to reveal the regional land-use change characteristics on the pattern of dynamic process and dynamic process of pattern.
challenges: It is too early to say that the trend of deforestation has been effectively reversed across China. There also exist conspicuous conflicts between arable land protection and urban expansion, as showed in the irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas.
dataset: The main data sources are Landsat TM digital images (520 scenes in 1995/1996 and 508 scenes in 1999/2000). Apart from that, the CBERS-1 (China-Brazil Earth Resources Satellite 1) data were also used to acquire land-use information for 1999/2000.
findings: There exists conspicuous regional differentiation of land-use change in China, which lays the foundation to draw the dynamic zones. The rapid change of land-use change during 1995—2000 happened in North China, Loess Plateau—agricultural and pasturing interlaced area, Northeast China, southeast coastal region, middle and lower reaches of Yangtze River, eastern coastal region.

background: Land cover plays a significant role in Earth system science, which reflects the influence of human activities and environmental changes. Reliable and up-to-date land cover data are very important for land, ecological and hydrological modelling, carbon and water cycle study as well as global climatic change study. Many land use/cover maps at global, continental, and regional scales have been produced in recent years using remote sensing. These four global land cover maps are all derived from remote sensing data and created for the same fundamental purpose of providing improved land cover information for scientific studies and environmental monitoring, but they are different in mapping methods, data sources, and classification systems.
research objective: The objective of this paper is to evaluate the application of the four popular land cover maps over China land mass. The possibility of developing a new land cover map whose classification is compatible with a well-accepted legend system but whose accuracy is more reliable also motivates this study.
challenges: The four maps used different classification systems, which made the comparison difficult. We conclude that the accuracies of all the datasets cannot meet the requirements of land surface modelling. For the reference data, i.e. the 1:100 000 land cover map, the classification system needs to be transferred to a well-recognized one that has been used commonly in land surface modelling.
methods: We compare and evaluate four land cover datasets over China. So we first aggregated these maps by reclassifying them using a unified legend system. A large-scale, i.e. 1:100 000 land cover map of China was used as the reference data to validate the four maps.
dataset: The datasets include the Version 2 global land cover dataset of IGBP, MODIS land cover map 2001, a global land cover map produced by the University of Maryland, and the land cover map produced by the global land cover for the year 2000 (GLC 2000) project coordinated by the Global Vegetation Monitoring Unit of the European Commission Joint Research Centre. The large-scale (1:100 000) land use map of China in 2000, which was produced by Chinese Academy of Science to meet large-scale resource survey and land use mapping, was used as truth to validate the four land cover maps over China.
findings: The results show that the GLC2000 land cover map represents the highest accuracy. The MODIS land cover map ranks second for type area consistency and third for sub-fraction overall accuracy compared with reference data. The IGBP land cover map has good labelling accuracy, although it has a local labelling error and third consistency for type area. The labelling accuracy and type area consistency for the reference data of UMd land cover map is low.

Verification.Question: Is the 1:100 000 land cover map of China used as a reference data to validate other land cover maps?

Disjunctive.Question: What type of satellite data collection method is predominantly used for land-use mapping in China, Landsat, CBERS-1, or both?
Which classification system is more effective for land cover maps in China, a well-recognized legend system or a custom classification system?

Concept Completion.Question: What data sources are typically used in creating land-use datasets for large-scale mapping projects?
Concept Completion.Answer: Landsat TM digital images, CBERS-1 data

Concept Completion.Question: Where can challenges in the classification systems of different land cover datasets be observed?
When is it essential to use a large-scale land use map as a reference for evaluating other land cover maps?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to validate land cover datasets in China?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to validate land cover datasets in China involves aggregating maps by reclassifying them using a unified legend system and using a large-scale (1:100 000) land cover map of China as the reference data to validate other land cover maps.

Example.Question: What is an example of the types of challenges faced when comparing different land use/cover datasets?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced when comparing land use/cover datasets is the use of different classification systems, which complicates the comparison process and affects the accuracies required for land surface modelling.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used to study land-use change in China during the late 1990s?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used for studying land-use change in China during the late 1990s includes Landsat TM digital images from 1995/1996 and 1999/2000, as well as CBERS-1 data for land-use information in 1999/2000.

Feature Specification.Question: What specific challenges might be encountered when comparing land cover maps with different classification systems?
Feature Specification.Answer: variations in classification methods, data sources, legend systems, aggregation and reclassification processes, consistent accuracy across different datasets

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics and methods are essential for evaluating the accuracy of land cover datasets?
Feature Specification.Answer: type area consistency, sub-fraction overall accuracy, labeling accuracy, unified legend system

Quantification.Question: What is the scale of the land use map produced by the Chinese Academy of Science to validate land cover maps over China?
How many primary and secondary classes are in the land cover classification system used in a dataset?

Definition.Question: What does 'land-use/cover change' entail in the context of global environmental change studies?
Definition.Answer: Land-use/cover change refers to alterations in the terrestrial surface material cycles and life-support processes, impacting the interaction between the biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, biogeochemical cycles, and the sustainable exploitation of resources.

Definition.Question: What is meant by a 'land cover map' in the context of remote sensing data?
Definition.Answer: A land cover map is a representation derived from remote sensing data that provides information on the types of land cover present in an area, which is vital for scientific studies and environmental monitoring.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used for the 1:100,000 land use map of China compare with those used for the global land cover maps like MODIS and GLC 2000?
Comparison.Answer: The 1:100,000 land use map of China was produced using Landsat TM and CBERS-1 satellite data, focusing on large-scale land use mapping at a detailed resolution. In contrast, global land cover maps like MODIS and GLC 2000 utilize different remote sensing data sources and classification systems to create broader-scale maps aimed at providing improved land cover information for scientific studies and environmental monitoring.

Interpretation.Question: What are potential challenges in harmonizing classification systems across different land cover datasets, and how might these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: One potential challenge is the use of different classification systems across datasets, which complicates comparisons. Addressing this involves reclassifying datasets using a unified legend system, which can facilitate better evaluation and comparison as demonstrated by the analysis of four global land cover maps over China.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the variation in land-use change dynamics across different regions in China during the 1995-2000 period?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variation in land-use change dynamics across China is influenced by conspicuous regional differentiation, which is linked to varied physical environments and vast land areas, leading to rapid changes in specific regions such as North China, Loess Plateau—agricultural and pasturing interlaced area, Northeast China, southeast coastal region, middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River, and eastern coastal region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do land cover datasets vary in their accuracy and classification systems when applied to land surface modeling in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Land cover datasets vary in their accuracy and classification systems due to the use of different mapping methods, data sources, and classification systems. This variation makes comparison difficult and indicates that the accuracies of the datasets may not meet the requirements for land surface modeling.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the conflict between arable land protection and urban expansion in China's land-use changes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The conflict between arable land protection and urban expansion is primarily caused by the irrational conversion from arable land to built-up areas, which is a significant challenge in effectively managing land-use changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind utilizing satellite remote sensing technologies like Landsat and CBERS-1 for collecting land-use data in China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to acquire comprehensive and accurate land-use information that can be used to study land-use/cover change, which is crucial for understanding the interaction between the biosphere and atmosphere, biodiversity, biogeochemical cycles, and sustainable resource exploitation.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to evaluate multiple global land cover maps to develop a new land cover map for China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The aim is to create a land cover map with a classification system that is compatible with well-accepted legend systems, ensuring accuracy and reliability for use in land, ecological, and hydrological modeling as well as climate change studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the importance of developing a dynamic regionalization of land-use change in China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to reveal the temporal and spatial features of land-use change, providing a foundation for studying regional scale land-use changes and understanding the impact of China's varied physical environments on social, economic development, and global change.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures can be implemented to integrate satellite-derived data with existing land use maps to enhance their accuracy in land-use change studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A potential approach involves using Landsat TM digital images and CBERS-1 data to acquire land-use information. These datasets were used for capturing land-use change information and could be compared or integrated with existing land use maps to enhance accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can different land cover classification systems be standardized for effective comparison and validation of land cover datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To standardize different land cover classification systems, one can reclassify datasets using a unified legend system. For validation, a large-scale reference map, such as the 1:100,000 land cover map of China, can be used to compare the datasets and assess their accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are necessary to evaluate the accuracy of global land cover datasets over a specific region like China?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The evaluation involves aggregating the global land cover datasets by reclassifying them using a unified legend system. The large-scale land use map of China can serve as reference data to validate these datasets, ensuring their compatibility and reliability over the region.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the integration of satellite remote sensing data for high-precision land use mapping?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies involve using satellite remote sensing data such as Landsat MSS, TM, and ETM, as well as CBERS-1 data, which provide the foundation for constructing detailed land use maps, with a classification system that divides land into multiple categories.

Enablement.Question: How do remote sensing advancements facilitate the evaluation of multiple global land cover maps for regional application?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing advancements allow the comparison and evaluation of various global land cover datasets, such as MODIS and GLC2000, by reclassifying them using a unified legend system and validating against a large-scale reference map like the 1:100 000 land use map of China.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or challenges influence the accuracy of land-use change assessments and land cover map comparisons?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include varied classification systems across different maps, the need for a compatible and well-recognized legend system, and the requirement for high accuracy in datasets to meet the demands of land surface modeling.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that different classification systems in land cover datasets may lead to challenges in comparing and integrating these datasets?
Expectation.Answer: The four maps used different classification systems, which made the comparison difficult. This indicates that varying classification systems can hinder direct comparison and integration due to inconsistencies in categorization, which could affect the reliability and applicability of the datasets for land surface modelling and other analyses.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that large-scale land cover maps with higher classification accuracy are necessary for reliable land surface modelling?
Expectation.Answer: The accuracies of all the datasets cannot meet the requirements of land surface modelling. The large-scale (1:100 000) land use map of China was used as truth to validate the four land cover maps over China. This indicates that higher accuracy in classification is essential to ensure the reliability of models that depend on precise land cover information to simulate environmental and climatic processes.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think current remote sensing techniques are in capturing the nuances of land-use change, and what improvements could be made?
Judgmental.Answer: Remote sensing techniques, such as those using Landsat TM and CBERS-1 data, have been effective in capturing regional differentiation of land-use change. However, challenges remain in classification system compatibility and accuracy for land surface modeling. Further improvements could involve developing a unified classification system and enhancing data accuracy through advanced sensor technologies.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the main challenges in achieving a consistent classification system for land-use datasets, and how can they be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges include the varied classification systems used in different datasets, making comparisons difficult. Addressing these challenges may require aggregating maps using a unified legend system and adjusting existing classification systems to align with well-recognized models used in land surface modeling.

Judgmental.Question: What potential do you see for integrating different global land cover maps to improve the accuracy of land-use studies, and what methods might facilitate this integration?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating different global land cover maps holds potential for improving accuracy, as shown by the evaluation of maps like GLC2000 and MODIS. Methods that might facilitate this integration include reclassifying maps using a common legend system and validating them against large-scale reference data to ensure consistency and accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when comparing different land cover datasets for a region as large as China.
Assertion.Answer: The main challenge in comparing different land cover datasets is the variation in classification systems used by each dataset, which complicates direct comparison. Additionally, accuracy levels of datasets may not meet the requirements for certain applications, necessitating reclassification and validation using a reference map.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the significance of using a unified legend system in evaluating multiple land cover maps.
Assertion.Answer: A unified legend system allows for the aggregation and reclassification of different land cover maps, facilitating a consistent comparison. This approach helps in evaluating the accuracy and utility of various datasets in representing land cover information reliably for scientific studies and environmental monitoring.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline potential datasets that could be used to validate land cover mapping accuracy and discuss how these datasets contribute to enhancing land-use change studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for validating land cover mapping accuracy include the Version 2 global land cover dataset of IGBP, MODIS land cover map 2001, University of Maryland's global land cover map, and the GLC 2000 project map. These datasets provide various classification perspectives and data sources, which can be validated against a large-scale map like the 1:100 000 land use map of China to improve the reliability and accuracy of land-use change studies.
